children.subject: I'm not the original anon, but I was wondering – what if I've taken 61C (and not 61B) before taking 170?

In terms of content, 61C and 170 have very little overlap, if any at all. As for skills, it's possible that 61C skills could come in handy in unexpected ways, but I don't think it would help that much. Same reasons as above, you'll want 61B for experience implementing data structures, graph theory, and more rigorous O notation stuff.

Yeah, that's part of why 61B is a prerequisite. Is your math background on par with CS 70? If so, then maybe this could work, but it still doesn't sound like a good idea. Keep in mind that CS 170 requires you to write and read pseudocode, and 61B is the class that gets you familiar with implementing algorithms/data structures and reading implementation code. 61A doesn't emphasize that as much.

history.content:
As someone taking 170 right now, what I can say is that the class does go over and somewhat reintroduce the data structures and algorithms taught in 61B, but not at a "beginners" level. In fact, the lecture tends to gloss over a lot of details of some of the repeated topics from 61B with the assumption that people have taken it (which they should have). I took 61B before taking 170, and I feel like I would be somewhat lost if I hadn't, since the class sort of assumes you've seen the graphs, data structures, sorting algs, etc. that might appear at the end of 61B, but you might see them right away in 170. And 170 then dives deeper into them, asking you to prove things about them, etc. (which is a CS70 skill), and going more into detail about performance than 61B. I would strongly recommend taking 70 and 61B before taking 170.

Take 61B with another CS requirement and really soak in (and enjoy!) 61B, it's one of the best classes in the department! And since it seems like you haven't taken 70 before either, I really wouldn't recommend taking 170 since they really just assume you can do proofs (you have to do them for literally every homework and that starts like in the first couple of weeks) and that's a skill that takes a lot of 70 exposure.

---

OP: I'm actually currently taking 70 and doing well (I had experience with discrete math and proofs beforehand). As I haven't really had a lot of exposure to 61B topics I'll probably take CS 170 later, then. Thanks!

Does CS 170 require prerequisite knowledge of algorithms taught in CS 61B? I have somewhat limited CS experience (APCS, CS61A right now) but a fairly strong math background.
history.subject: CS 170 concurrently with CS 61B
